sect2.title: /dev/i2c-* versus PCI memory
sect2.para: To control a monitor, DDCcontrol must access to the I2C bus of the graphics card. There are two methods to do so: the first one uses /dev/i2c-* devices provided by kernel drivers (abbreviated by dev in tables), the second one reads and writes directly in the card PCI memory (abbreviated by PCI in the tables).
Depending on your hardware, one method or the other works, or even both.

sect2.title: Direct PCI memory access support
sect2.para: Almost every nVidia cards work with direct PCI memory access, and this method is compatible with the nVidia proprietary drivers.
To use it, you have nothing special to do, everything is done by DDCcontrol.

sect2.title: /dev/i2c-* devices support
sect2.note: To use /dev/i2c-* devices with nVidia cards, you must have a rather recent kernel (at least version 2.6.9).
sect2.para: Most nVidia cards, starting with TNT, but excluding the most recent GeForce FX series, work with /dev/i2c-* devices. To use them, you must load the rivafb module by typing, as root:
The kernel configuration options needed to enable nVidia framebuffer and I2C support are:

itemizedlist.listitem: Devices drivers Graphics support Framebuffer support nVidia Riva support .
Devices drivers Graphics support Framebuffer support nVidia Riva support Enable DDC Support .

warning.para: The rivafb kernel module is not compatible with the binary nVidia X drivers, which are the only drivers for nVidia cards to provide 3D acceleration.
This is why we recommend that you use direct PCI memory access with nVidia cards.

sect2.title: i810/i815/i830/i845/i855/i865/i915/i945 with Integrated Graphics Controller
sect2.para: Intel integrated graphics controllers only works with direct PCI memory access, so you don't have to have any kernel module built or loaded.
